      COX NEWS SERVICE THURSDAY FEATURES BUDGET
      c. 1998 Cox News Service

   These feature stories for release Thursday, June 4, 1998, are
moving today to clients of the New York Times News Service.

   Separate budgets move daily with spot news, sports, business and
commentary.

   Stories are moving in the category they're listed under. Stories
moving to duplicate categories are marked. All stories have moved
except those with an ETA.

   If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the
Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456.

   LIFESTYLE (l category)

   NETWATCH _ ATLANTA _ For those of you who know nothing about
soccer, the World Cup is the best place to learn. One way for
clueless Americans to bone up on World Cup news is on the Web.
(Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/2. (f, l)

   MILKMAN _ ATLANTA _ Rick Lee, one of the last milkmen in
Atlanta, who is also a poet/writer, leaves poems with his customers
(some days). His truck isn't the old milk truck, but a pickup with
a cooler cab on the back. We ride with him (starting at 3 a.m.) on
his Friday route. (Scott, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) ETA 8 p.m.
ET.

   WOMEN-KICKBOXING _ ATLANTA _ More women are getting a kick out
of exercise. They're lining up for kick-boxing classes, and
punching out their frustrations. Classes aren't as hot as on the
West Coast, but they're warming up. (Kim, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA 8 p.m. ET.

   POOL-SAFETY _ How do you keep kids out of a pool, or get them to
use it safely? A study in the medical journal Pediatrics says
fences are effective only 19 percent of the time. So what works?
(Hill, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) ETA 8 p.m. ET.

   FOOD (d category)

   BEER-MSKUBE _ When you're choosing an Asian beer, you want to
remember that they aren't ``Asian.'' With a few exceptions, they're
pale lagers, no different in style from those you'd find the world
over. (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/2.

   PEANUT-CHICKEN _ This chicken crisps as it cools, which makes it
ideal for picnics. It's a favorite with the Junior League of
Charlotte, N.C., which included it in its cookbook, Dining by
Fireflies: The Unexpected Pleasures of the New South (Delmar
Printing and Publishing, $21.95). (recipe follows). (Walker,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/2. EMBARGOED UNTIL 6/4.

   WITH

   FOOD-RECIPESWAP _ For a strictly peanut butter candy, we turned
to a classic Southern cookbook, ``Charleston Receipts,'' a
collection of recipes gathered by the Junior League of Charleston,
S.C., in 1950. Sure enough, we found a recipe for Peanut Butter
Fudge Dreams. (Walker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/2.
EMBARGOED UNTIL 6/4.

   TRAVEL

   TRAVEL-LANIER _ Lake Lanier Islands, Ga. _ Our paddleboat sank
during a recent jam-packed weekend escape to one of Atlanta's
favorite playgrounds. But not our spirits. Among many new
improvements to the park, the new LakeHouses on Lanier are part of
$10 million in capital improvements made by California-based KSL
Recreation Corp. since it took over ownership and operation of Lake
Lanier Islands from the state last summer. In addition to building
the 30 LakeHouses, KSL has upgraded the 224-room Hilton Resort.
(Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/2.

   TRAVEL-CALENDAR _ A list of Southern festivals throughout the
summer. (Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/2.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e category)

   TVSURFER-COLUMN _ ATLANTA _ A quick chat with TBS' ``Dinner & a
Movie'' hosts Paul Gilmartin and Annabelle Gurwitch, who've taped
several new spots for June and July, including June 12's ``Sleeping
With The Enemy'' (the recipe: Pecan Someone Your Own Size Pie).
ETA: 8 p.m. ET.

   CARREY _ Actor Jim Carrey talks to us about morphing himself
into a more serious comic actor, evident in his new film ``The
Truman Show,'' opening June 5. Quotes from Carrey, his co-star
Laura Linney and director Peter Weir. (Ringel, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA: 8 p.m. ET.

   with

   CARREY-LIST _ Carrey's career in movies.

   CNN-NEWSSTAND _ ATLANTA _ Sunday night, for the first time in 17
years, James Earl Jones will not intone ``This is CNN.'' Instead,
he'll say, ``This is CNN NewsStand.'' The brief but telling break
with tradition is the network's way of signaling that ``NewsStand''
is not news as usual. The new magazine show, keyed to ``Time,''
``Fortune'' and ``Entertainment Weekly,'' is CNN's biggest
initiative ever, an attempt to get viewers to think differently
about the network. (Kloer, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) ETA: 8
p.m. ET.

   with

   CNN-SIDE _ Sidebar on nuts and bolts of what's in each program,
including specific stories.

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers
